item.title: Javax.swing.timer?
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

supamagier:

I would suggest using a Thread…

i would suggest you learn more about his situation before suggesting,
we dont know what he is using it for,

if he wants to make a caret blink, a timer is better

openice123, from your post, its not completely clear what you question is, rewrite your post to make it clearer,

one thing iv noticed is you dont have any handler for the timer

timer = new Timer(delay, new ActionListener() {
    public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent evt) {
          //do stuff here
    }
});

item.title: Javax.swing.timer?
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

When you create a timer, every time the delay goes to 0, it sets off an ActionEvent. You need an ActionListener to handle it.

Read full topic

item.title: Javax.swing.timer?
item.dc:creator: @openice123 openice123
item.description:
@openice123 wrote:

[size=10pt]dont need anymore help[/size]

i kinda have an idea of how to make but its probably wrong

import javax.swing.Timer;

public int timer(int delay, int start) { Timer timer; timer = new Timer(delay, null); timer.setInitialDelay(start); timer.start(); return delay; }

im thinking that returning the delay would restart the action
and when the integer start hits the number you want the action will start
